title: JavaScript: The Language of the Web

modules.title: Module 1: JS Introduction
modules.description: Get started with JavaScript syntax, variables, and data types.

lessons.title: JS Output
lessons.theory: JavaScript can display data in different ways: innerHTML, document.write(), window.alert(), and console.log().
lessons.code: JavaScript Output

quiz.question: Which method writes data into an HTML element?

lessons.title: JS Variables
lessons.theory: Variables are containers for storing data. JavaScript has 3 ways to declare variables: var, let, and const.
lessons.code: JavaScript Variables

quiz.question: Which keyword defines a variable that cannot be reassigned?

lessons.title: JS Data Types
lessons.theory: JavaScript variables can hold different data types: numbers, strings, objects, booleans, etc.
lessons.code: JavaScript Data Types

quiz.question: What data type is 'Hello World'?

project.title: Variable Playground
project.description: Create a script that declares variables of different types and displays them.

lessons.title: JS Operators
lessons.theory: JavaScript operators are used to perform arithmetic, assignment, comparison, logical, and type operations.
lessons.code: JavaScript Operators

quiz.question: Which operator is used for multiplication?

lessons.title: JS If...Else
lessons.theory: Conditional statements are used to perform different actions based on different conditions.
lessons.code: JavaScript if..else

quiz.question: How do you write an IF statement in JavaScript?

lessons.title: JS Loops
lessons.theory: Loops can execute a block of code a number of times.
lessons.code: JavaScript For Loop

quiz.question: Which loop is best when you know how many times to loop?

project.title: Number Checker
project.description: Write a script that checks if a number is even or odd.

lessons.title: JS Functions
lessons.theory: A JavaScript function is a block of code designed to perform a particular task.
lessons.code: JavaScript Functions

quiz.question: How do you create a function in JavaScript?

lessons.title: Arrow Functions
lessons.theory: Arrow functions allow for a shorter syntax for writing function expressions.
lessons.code: JavaScript Arrow Function

quiz.question: Arrow functions were introduced in which version?

project.title: Temperature Converter
project.description: Create functions to convert between Celsius and Fahrenheit.

lessons.title: JS Objects
lessons.theory: Objects are variables too. But objects can contain many values. The values are written as name:value pairs.
lessons.code: JavaScript Objects

quiz.question: How do you access an object property?

lessons.title: JS Arrays
lessons.theory: An array is a special variable, which can hold more than one value.
lessons.code: JavaScript Arrays

quiz.question: How do you access the first element of an array?

lessons.title: Array Methods
lessons.theory: JavaScript provides many methods to work with arrays, like push(), pop(), shift(), unshift(), map(), filter(), etc.
lessons.code: JavaScript Array Methods

quiz.question: Which method removes the last element from an array?

project.title: To-Do List Data
project.description: Manage a list of tasks using an array and object methods.

modules.title: Module 5: The DOM
modules.description: Manipulating the HTML Document Object Model.

lessons.title: DOM Introduction
lessons.theory: With the HTML DOM, JavaScript can access and change all the elements of an HTML document.
lessons.code:
Finding HTML Elements

Hello World!

quiz.question: What does DOM stand for?

lessons.title: Changing CSS
lessons.theory: JavaScript can change the style of HTML elements.
lessons.code:
JavaScript HTML DOM

Hello World!

quiz.question: How do you change the background color of an element?

lessons.title: DOM Events
lessons.theory: HTML events are 'things' that happen to HTML elements. JavaScript can react to these events.
lessons.code: JavaScript Events

quiz.question: Which event occurs when the user clicks on an HTML element?

project.title: Interactive Button
project.description: Create a button that changes the background color of the page when clicked.

lessons.title: Async/Await
lessons.theory: Async/Await makes promises easier to write. 'async' makes a function return a Promise. 'await' makes a function wait for a Promise.
lessons.code: JavaScript Async/Await

quiz.question: The keyword 'await' can only be used inside which type of function?

lessons.title: Fetch API
lessons.theory: The Fetch API interface allows web browser to make HTTP requests to web servers.
lessons.code:
JavaScript Fetch API

Fetching data...

quiz.question: What does the fetch() method return?

project.title: Data Fetcher
project.description: Simulate fetching user data and displaying it on the page.

modules.title: Module 7: ES6+ Features
modules.description: Learn the modern features introduced in ECMAScript 2015 and beyond.

lessons.title: let and const
lessons.theory: let and const are modern variable declarations. let is block-scoped and can be reassigned, while const is block-scoped and cannot be reassigned.
lessons.code:
JavaScript let and const

let allows you to declare variables that are limited to the scope of a block statement, or expression on which it is used.

Using const is good practice when declaring a variable that should not change.

quiz.question: What is the scope of a variable declared with 'let'?

lessons.title: Arrow Functions
lessons.theory: Arrow functions provide a more concise syntax for writing function expressions.
lessons.code:
JavaScript Arrow Functions

Arrow functions allows a short syntax for writing function expressions.

quiz.question: Which syntax is correct for an arrow function?

lessons.title: Template Literals
lessons.theory: Template literals provide an easy way to interpolate variables and expressions inside strings.
lessons.code: JavaScript Template Literals

quiz.question: What character is used to enclose template literals?

lessons.title: Spread Operator
lessons.theory: The spread operator allows an iterable to expand in places where 0+ arguments are expected.
lessons.code: JavaScript Spread Operator

quiz.question: Which operator is the spread operator?

lessons.title: Destructuring
lessons.theory: Destructuring allows you to unpack values from arrays, or properties from objects, into distinct variables.
lessons.code: JavaScript Destructuring

quiz.question: What does destructuring do?

project.title: ES6+ Feature Showcase
project.description: Create a webpage that demonstrates the use of let/const, arrow functions, template literals, spread operator, and destructuring.

lessons.title: Class Syntax
lessons.theory: Use the keyword class to create a class. Always add a method named constructor().
lessons.code: JavaScript Classes

quiz.question: Which keyword is used to create a class?

lessons.title: Class Inheritance
lessons.theory: To create a class inheritance, use the extends keyword. A class created with a class inheritance inherits all the methods from another class.
lessons.code: JavaScript Class Inheritance

quiz.question: Which keyword is used to inherit from another class?

lessons.title: Static Methods
lessons.theory: Static methods are defined on the class itself, and cannot be called on objects created from the class.
lessons.code: JavaScript Static Methods

quiz.question: Can you call a static method on an instantiated object?

project.title: Car Factory
project.description: Create a Car class and a Truck subclass, then instantiate them.

modules.title: Module 9: JSON and Storage
modules.description: Handling data formats and client-side storage.

lessons.title: JSON Syntax
lessons.theory: JSON stands for JavaScript Object Notation. It is a lightweight data interchange format. JSON is text, written with JavaScript object notation.
lessons.code: JavaScript JSON

quiz.question: Which method converts a JavaScript object into a string?

lessons.title: LocalStorage
lessons.theory: The localStorage object allows you to save key/value pairs in the browser. The data is not deleted when the browser is closed.
lessons.code: JavaScript localStorage

quiz.question: Does localStorage data expire?

project.title: User Preferences
project.description: Create a page that saves the user's name in localStorage and greets them when they return.

modules.title: Final Assessment
modules.description: Prove your mastery to unlock the certificate.

lessons.title: JavaScript Final Exam
lessons.theory:
This is the final assessment for the JavaScript course.
Rules:
  • There are 30 questions.
  • You need a score of 80% (24/30) to pass.
  • You have a maximum of 3 attempts.
  • The certificate will unlock automatically upon passing.

project.title: Final Review
project.description: Review all modules before taking the final exam.
